Authors:
Elida Cavalcanti Marins, Maria Jussara Santos Silva,
Jackeline Laurentino da Silva, Janaine Rossane Araújo Silva-Cabral,
Jaqueline Figueredo de Oliveira Costa, Frederico Monteiro Feijó,
Iraildes Pereira Assuncao, Gaus Silvestre de Andrade Lima
Title:
Colletotrichum species associated with sugar cane red
rot
Keywords:
Multilocus analysis, Diversity of fungi, Saccharum spp.,
Pathogenicity.
Abstract:
The sugarcane is a widely cultivated culture in Brazil and
in the world. However, the red rot causes large losses due to the
reduction of sucrose and deterioration of the juice. Thus, the aim of
this study was to identify Colletotrichum species associated with the
red rot through polyphasic approaches, which included phylogenetic,
morpho-cultural analyzes and pathogenicity tests. Nine isolates from
Alagoas and two from São Paulo, Brazil, were preliminary analyzed with
the glyceraldehyde-3 phosphate dehydrogenase gene (GAPDH), as an initial
measure of species diversity. Posteriorly, the representative isolates
of each species were sequenced with the β-tubulin (TUB2) gene,
calmodulin (CAL) and the ITS-rDNA region. For the morpho-cultural
characterization the mycelial growth rate (MGR), the colonies aspect,
the shape and size of 50 conidia and appressoria of the isolates were
observed. For the pathogenicity test asymptomatic leaves and stems of
sugarcane were used with and without injuries. The phylogenetic analysis
associated with morpho-cultural characteristics and the pathogenicity
test of the eleven isolates revealed three Colletotrichum species: C.
falcatum, C. siamense and C. plurivorum. All of the species were
pathogenic in leaves and stems with injuries, the species C. falcatum
being the one that showed the biggest lesions (1.12 cm) in leaves and C.
plurivorum in the stems (0.67 cm). This study shows the first report of
C. siamense and C. plurivorum species associated with sugarcane red rot
in the world.
